interconnection.net_metering_details: Kansas requires net metering from IOUs for systems up to 200 kW (residential) and 200 kW (commercial). Credits at retail rate. Monthly rollover. Evergy (formerly Westar/KCP&L) is the dominant IOU. Municipal utilities and co-ops have varying policies.
interconnection.fees: Varies by utility; typically minimal for residential systems

special_considerations.hoa_restrictions: Kansas studied HOA solar restriction regulations but has no comprehensive solar access law. HOAs may restrict solar installations.
special_considerations.historic_districts: Historic districts in Dodge City, Lawrence, and other cities have local review requirements. Kansas State Historic Preservation Office consulted for National Register properties.
special_considerations.wind_load_requirements: High wind areas, especially in western Kansas tornado alley. Design wind speeds 90-120 mph. Tornado resistance not specifically required but enhanced mounting recommended.
special_considerations.snow_load_requirements: Moderate snow loads (15-25 psf ground snow load). Western Kansas may have higher requirements due to blowing/drifting snow.

licensing.license_type: No dedicated state solar license. Licensed electrician required for electrical work. City/county contractor licensing varies.

notes: Kansas has a growing solar market but remains primarily a wind energy state. Net metering at retail rate is favorable. No state solar tax credit. Property tax exemption available for residential solar systems. Evergy is the primary utility serving most of the population. Rural areas served by cooperatives may have different policies. High wind conditions require attention to mounting system selection and engineering.
